text: With respect, you are then unlikely to find anything. My approach is to start with a theory. You then test that theory. Others may follow similar approach. For example: “Faster dogs win races. I believe there would be a weight to box relationship, and heavier dogs have an advantage if mid starters”. [I’m not suggesting this is a valid theory, but you see I now would have something to test]. Next step, ask what data you need to collect - timeframe, tracks, starter numbers, sample size. Go and collect a rich dataset then test you theory. And along the way you’ll use pandas :wink:

text: Yeah my point is that you look for areas of discrepancy, you can't just take the mean of all possible bets that will always be zero. The bets you strike are a subset of all possible bets. One way to do this graphically is just to calculate Y as 1/price - win (encoded 0 or 1) for each line then group the results according to some variable X, take the mean of your Y values for each group and plot a line. If your variable is useful it'll make some kind of shape, if it isn't you'll just see a flat line at Y = 0.

elements.text: Yeah my point is that you look for areas of discrepancy, you can't just take the mean of all possible bets that will always be zero. The bets you strike are a subset of all possible bets. One way to do this graphically is just to calculate Y as 1/price - win (encoded 0 or 1) for each line then group the results according to some variable X, take the mean of your Y values for each group and plot a line. If your variable is useful it'll make some kind of shape, if it isn't you'll just see a flat line at Y = 0.

text: Your other simple option is to calculate the profit on a bet on every line, group that and plot it directly.

elements.text: Your other simple option is to calculate the profit on a bet on every line, group that and plot it directly.

text: If you just plot price against outcome it can be hard to see the difference between the two lines but if you plot the discrepancy directly it's much easier to see the trend or shape or whatever.

elements.text: If you just plot price against outcome it can be hard to see the difference between the two lines but if you plot the discrepancy directly it's much easier to see the trend or shape or whatever.

text: So this may seem a silly question, but when you say "on each line", what do you mean by "line"?

elements.text: So this may seem a silly question, but when you say "on each line", what do you mean by "line"?

text:
I mean each row of your dataframe.

X is your variable, Y is the discrepancy between the price and the actual rate of winning. So you make a column called 'price_edge' or whatever's meaningful to you - that's your Y and then group that into bands of X, so if you've got X encoded between 0 and 1 your bands might be 0-0.1, 0.1-0.2 etc. Take the average of Y for each group and plot. The further your values of Y are from 0 the better your Ferrari.

elements.text:
I mean each row of your dataframe.

X is your variable, Y is the discrepancy between the price and the actual rate of winning. So you make a column called 'price_edge' or whatever's meaningful to you - that's your Y and then group that into bands of X, so if you've got X encoded between 0 and 1 your bands might be 0-0.1, 0.1-0.2 etc. Take the average of Y for each group and plot. The further your values of Y are from 0 the better your Ferrari.

text: So if you're looking at a 10 second price movement the sensible way to do that would be (1 / price at T minus 10 secs) - (1 / price at T) which will give you values between -1 and +1, but really they'll all be in a much smaller range like +-0.05. Split that into maybe 10 groups and plot against Y.

elements.text: So if you're looking at a 10 second price movement the sensible way to do that would be (1 / price at T minus 10 secs) - (1 / price at T) which will give you values between -1 and +1, but really they'll all be in a much smaller range like +-0.05. Split that into maybe 10 groups and plot against Y.

text: It doesn’t need to be art. You need to add in a dimension to the analysis. How does it look at different times until the off? And also consider filtering by price range. So, is the behaviour different at different price levels and at different times before start? You may be looking for a strategy that only works for a period of the market.

elements.text: It doesn’t need to be art. You need to add in a dimension to the analysis. How does it look at different times until the off? And also consider filtering by price range. So, is the behaviour different at different price levels and at different times before start? You may be looking for a strategy that only works for a period of the market.
